review.title: Soft Goals Can Be Compiled Away
review.abstract: Soft goals extend the classical model of planning with a simple model of preferences. The best plans are then not the ones with least cost but the ones with maximum utility, where the utility of a plan is the sum of the utilities of the soft goals achieved minus the plan cost. Finding plans with high utility appears to involve two linked problems: choosing a subset of soft goals to achieve and finding a low-cost plan to achieve them. New search algorithms and heuristics have been developed for planning with soft goals, and a new track has been introduced in the International Planning Competition (IPC) to test their performance. In this note, we show however that these extensions are not needed: soft goals do not increase the expressive power of the basic model of planning with action costs, as they can easily be compiled away. We apply this compilation to the problems of the net-benefit track of the most recent IPC, and show that optimal and satisficing cost-based planners do better on the compiled problems than optimal and satisficing net-benefit planners on the original problems with explicit soft goals. Furthermore, we show that penalties, or negative preferences expressing conditions to avoid, can also be compiled away using a similar idea.

sections.heading: 3. Experimental Results
sections.text: This year, we have reached the point where we are able to integrate in a country where most people are able to leave a country, where they are able to integrate, and where they are able to integrate in order to flourish.

sections.heading: 4. Extensions
sections.text: We have shown that it is possible to collect positive aid programmes linked to individual aid programmes. We now show that this compilation can be expanded to deal with positive aid programmes defined on formulas above liquid funds and negative aid programmes defined on both individual aid programmes and formulas. Negative aid programmes stand for conditions that are to be avoided rather than sought after; for example, an aid programme punishing a plan that leads to a state in which both p and q are defined at an additional cost of 10. The compilation of soft targets defined on formulas is based on the standard set of target and precondition formulas in classical planning (Gazen & Knoblock, 1997; Fog, 1999). A positive aid programme based on a logical formula A can be put together by introducing a new flowing aid programme that can be achieved at zero cost by any final state in which A, and the allocation of aid programme to A.

sections.heading: 5. Summary
sections.text: We have shown that soft targets do not add meaningfulness and can be easily compiled away, which means that no new search algorithms or heuristics are required to handle them. On a practical level, experiments suggest that modern sequence planners outperform more modern net benefit planners in assembled versions of the benchmarks used in recent planning competitions. Furthermore, similar transformations can be used to summarize positive and negative tools on logical formulas in DNF or CNF.

The SO planners we test on the compiled versions of the NBO problems are the SO versions of Gamer (Edelkamp & Kissmann, 2008) and Mips-XXL (Edelkamp & Jabbar, 2008) and the two SO planners HSPF and HSP * 0 (Haslum, 2008).

These results appear to contradict the results reported by Benton et al. (2009), where the native net-benefit planner, YochanPS, yields better results than a cost-based planner, YochanCOST, run on problems compiled according to an earlier version of our transformation (Keyder & Geffner, 2007).

The discrepancy appears to be the result of the non-informative cost-based heuristic used in YochanCOST, which leads to plans that forgo all soft goals, and the fact that they do not make use of the optimization discussed at the end of Section 2, which results in an unnecessary blowup of the state space. For an analysis of the differences between some recent cost-based planners, see the paper by Keyder and Geffner (2008).
